Project Description  The  Western  Basins  Water  Resources  Management  Project  (the 
Project)  will  support  infrastructure  development,  strengthening  of 
institutional  frameworks,  and  capacity  development  for  water 
resources  management  and  irrigated  agriculture  in  the  western 
basins of Afghanistan (Badghis, Ghowr, and Herat provinces), mainly 
comprising the Hari Rud River Basin, which includes Herat, and the 
Murghab  River  Basin.  The  Project  has  four  components:  (i) 
integrated  water  resources  management  (IWRM),  (ii)  water 
resources and irrigation development, (iii) agriculture and livelihood 
services, and (iv) capacity development and project management. 
 
The IWRM component will support technical studies for surface and 
groundwater  to  improve  the  knowledge  base  to  manage  water 
resources in the Hari Rud River Basin. The Project also seeks to 
strengthen the institutional frameworks and capacity for surface water 
allocation and groundwater management as a part of river basin 
management. It will support the eventual formation of a river basin 
authority in line with the water resources policy of the Ministry of 
Energy and Water (MEW). The Project will support development of 
planning and management options through the river basin authority 
to  allocate  water  resources  efficiently  and  equitably  for  basin 
development. 
 
The  water  resources  and  irrigation  development  component  will 
provide  for  the  rehabilitation  and  upgrading  (R&U)  of  55,000  to 
65,000  hectares  (ha)  of  traditional  irrigation  systems.  Traditional 
irrigation makes up over 80% of the irrigated area in Afghanistan; the 
systems were developed by communities as long as 700 years ago. 
The  Project  will  rehabilitate  entire  systems  and  enhance  system 
intakes improving their capture efficiency and increasing late season 
water supplies. The Project will also provide capacity development 
for   MEW   staff   (the Irrigation Department)  as  well   as for  mirabs,

iii
  who are the traditional community managers of irrigation systems 
and responsible for overseeing system management and operation 
and maintenance (O&M). The Project will also support development 
of small-scale water resources infrastructure. 
 
The  Project’s  agriculture  and  livelihood  services  component  will 
ensure that the improved water supply from the irrigation system 
R&U is used most effectively to increase the productivity of irrigated 
agriculture and that project benefits are equitably distributed. This 
component will also ensure that farmers have viable alternatives to 
poppy production, although poppy is not widely grown in the western 
basins. On-farm water management training will be given for farmers 
and mirabs. Agricultural extension will be provided to improve wheat 
yields  (the  primary  staple  crop  grown  by  most  farmers)  and  to 
stimulate second season, higher value horticulture crops. The Project 
will  support  farmer  training,  demonstration  plots,  and  community-
developed  trials.  The  Project  will  provide  income-generating 
opportunities targeted at women and the landless through training, 
start-up materials, and ongoing technical support. Possible activities 
will  include  mulberry  and  sericulture  (silkworm  raising),  poultry 
raising, and livestock programs. 
 
Given Afghanistan’s severe capacity constraints, the Project will 
feature  an  important  and  cross-cutting  capacity  development 
component. The Project will provide training, equipment, and other 
resource  materials  for  ministry  staff,  mirabs,  farmers,  and 
participants in the livelihoods services activities. Both domestic and 
international education will be supported through the Project. 
 
Rationale  Water  resources  management  and  irrigated  agriculture  are 
fundamental to the well-being of the national economy, the rural 
sector, and poverty reduction. Irrigated agriculture produces up to 
80% of total agricultural output, with agriculture comprising between 
50% and 60% of the national economy and employing up to 80% of 
the  country’s  population.  Farmers  throughout  the  country  have 
cited  lack  of  irrigation  water  as  the  primary  constraint  to 
agricultural productivity. A drought in 2004 caused the  projected 
16% annual   growth  in  gross    domestic  product  to  be  revised

iv   
  downward  to  8%  and  resulted  in  some  2.5  million  Afghans 
  experiencing  food  insecurity.  Developing  water  resources  and 
  improving  the  productivity  of  irrigated  agriculture  thus  are 
paramount  to  sustaining  economic  growth  and  addressing  rural 
poverty.  Agriculture  uses  95%  of  developed  water  supplies,  so 
enhancement of irrigated agriculture must be pursued in parallel 
with strengthening water resources management. 
 
Decades of civil unrest have impeded maintenance and repairs to the 
existing irrigation systems of the western basins, and they are in 
urgent need of assistance, with the entire canal networks needing 
R&U. The irrigation systems can also be rationalized to operate more 
efficiently and increase the total irrigated area. Canal intakes can be 
upgraded to increase capture of low season flows and to prevent 
flood damage and sediment deposition. Because of the degraded 
condition of systems, cropping intensity in the western basins was 
only 40% at the end of the severe drought from 1999 to 2001. Mirabs 
and communities have traditionally provided management and O&M 
for the systems. However, given the extremely dilapidated condition 
of the irrigation systems, additional resources and technical support 
are needed beyond what the mirabs and community can provide to 
(i) return the systems to good condition to ensure that communities 
can sustain their operation, and (ii) enhance their performance for 
more productive irrigated agriculture. R&U of the systems will provide 
more  reliable  water  supply  thereby  increasing  the  irrigated  area, 
improving  yields  for  first  season  crops,  and  providing  for  more 
opportunities and better yields for second season crops.  
 
Improving  the  management  of  surface  water,  groundwater,  and 
water quality in the Hari Rud River Basin is critical to agricultural 
intensification  and  economic  growth.  Although  traditional  water 
allocations among irrigation systems exist, these allocations need to 
be  rationalized.  Significant  groundwater  potential  exists,  but 
available  information  is  inadequate  to  manage  its  sustainable 
exploitation.  An  improved  institutional  framework  and  capacity 
development are also required to manage such activities. 
 
Farmers have been living with uncertain water supply and thus 
engaging  in  relatively  low  productivity  agriculture  for  centuries. 
Wheat is mainly planted in the winter or spring and is the primary 
irrigated  crop  taken  in  the  spring.  Yields  of  irrigated  wheat  are 
typically low at 2.0 tons/ha in the Hari Rud River Valley, although 
rainfed yields are even lower at less than 1 ton/ha. Limited summer 
crops are taken when and where water is available; in upstream 
areas rice is taken as a second crop in addition to vegetables. The 
output of   vineyards   and  orchards  has   declined   due  to neglect 
during  the  civil  unrest as  well  as  recent drought.  With  improved

v
  irrigation systems and water supply, significant opportunities exist 
for farmers to improve agricultural productivity through better on-
farm  water  management  with  better  agricultural  practices  from 
extension activities. 
 
In  summary,  the  western  basins  have  significant  potential  for 
agriculture  intensification  through  R&U  of  existing  irrigation 
systems, and exploitation of groundwater. However, farmers need 
assistance  to  manage  water  most  effectively  and  agricultural 
support take advantage of cropping opportunities. 
 
Impact and Outcome  The  Project  will  improve  rural  livelihoods  through  strengthened 
IWRM,  improved  irrigation  service  delivery,  and  enhanced 
agricultural  practices  to  increase  the  productivity  of  irrigated 
agriculture  in  the  western  basins.  The  primary  project  impacts 
include (i) improved IWRM and water management, (ii) R&U and 
development of irrigation and water resources infrastructure, (iii) 
enhanced support for improved agricultural productivity and rural 
livelihoods,  and  (iv)  developed  capacity  and  strengthened 
institutional frameworks for IWRM and irrigated agriculture.

Arrangements  implementing agencies will be MEW; Ministry of Agriculture, Animal 
Husbandry,  and  Food;  and  Ministry  of  Mines  and  Industry.  Two 
project committees will be formed: (i) a project steering committee in 
Kabul, co-chaired by either the minister or deputy minister of MEW

a representative from the governor’s office in Herat and comprising

Basin. In addition, the PMU will oversee all financial management,

deputy project director will be opened in Obe, Herat Province, for 
activities in the upper Hari Rud River Basin and possibly in Badghis 
Province for the Murghab Basin. The PMU will maintain an office in 
Kabul with a deputy project director to coordinate project activities 
with MEW headquarters until such capacity exists within MEW.

The Project as a whole yields an economic internal rate of return of

Risks and Assumptions  Security. The overall political and security situation in Afghanistan 
remains not fully stable, although the majority of the western basins 
is one of the most secure areas in the country. The Project will 
require vigilant monitoring and close coordination with the United 
Nations and local authorities to ensure project-related security. 
 
Contracting of Civil Works. Due to the prolonged civil unrest and 
stagnation  of  construction  in  the  area,  concern  exists  that  local

The  Project  will  use  a  variety  of  contracting  and  procurement

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan, 
and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the Western Basins Water 
Resources Management Project (the Project). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  Water resources management and irrigated agriculture are fundamental to the well-being of 
the national economy, the rural sector, and poverty reduction in Afghanistan. Irrigated agriculture 
produces up to 80% of agricultural output with agriculture comprising between 50% and 60% of the 
national economy and employing about 80% of the population. Farmers throughout the country 
have cited lack of irrigation water as the primary constraint to agricultural productivity, and deficit 
rainfall in 2004 caused the projected 16% annual growth in gross domestic product to be revised 
downward to 8% and resulted in 2.5 million Afghans facing food insecurity. Developing water 
resources  and  improving  the  productivity  of  irrigated  agriculture  is  paramount  to  promoting 
Afghanistan’s economic growth and addressing rural poverty(Appendix 2). Agriculture uses 95% of 
developed water supplies, so enhancement of irrigated agriculture must be pursued in parallel with 
strengthening water resources management.1 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  The Western Basins. Badghis, Ghowr, and Herat provinces comprise the western basins. 
With the exception of Herat City, the districts in the western basins are nearly 100% rural with over 
2 million people. Up to 30% of rural households are landless, up to 80% consider themselves poor 
or very poor, and the average farm size is less than 1 hectare (ha). The Hari Rud and Murghab 
Rivers are the largest in western Afghanistan; together their basins cover 78,000 square kilometers 
(12% of Afghanistan). The two rivers provide 3 billion cubic meters of annual water runoff, split 
almost equally between the two basins, and flow into Turkmenistan with the Hari Rud River Basin 
first traveling along the border with Iran. The Hari Rud River Basin is far more developed and 
includes Herat City. Runoff comes from snowmelt with high flood flows from March to June and 
very low flows from August to February. For irrigation, discharge is excess in the spring and deficit 
in the summer. Farmers have adapted their irrigation and agricultural practices to this flood regime. 
The  Hari  Rud  River  Basin  has  significant  groundwater  potential,  which  has  been  largely 
unexploited. Installation of shallow and deep wells is increasing and will accelerate as incomes 
rise.  Although  the  use  of  groundwater  offers  tremendous  opportunity,  insufficient  information 
currently exists to quantify the impact of its development and to manage it. 
 
4.  Irrigated Agriculture. The Hari Rud River Basin contains some of the most extensive 
irrigated areas in Afghanistan. Local communities developed the irrigation systems to provide 
water for irrigation, livestock, and domestic use over 500 years ago, and they have sophisticated 
water allocation methods. The western basins have about 300,000 ha of irrigated area, of which 
170,000 ha are intensively irrigated with 110,000 ha (63% of intensive irrigation) found in the lower 
Hari Rud River Basin.2 Most of the intermittently irrigated areas are located in the upper Hari Rud 
River Basin (62%). Smaller systems are scattered in the upper Hari Rud and Murghab River 
Basins. System size is mainly a function of water availability (accessibility and reliability) and land 
suitability (soil type and topography).

5.  Wheat is the primary crop grown in irrigated areas and is taken as the first season crop. 
Fodder is the next most common crop, accounting for 10% of irrigated areas. In areas with secure 
water supply, higher value second season or perennial crops are grown including rice, orchards, 
vineyards, and vegetables. In rainfed areas, opportunistic crops of winter wheat and fodder are 
grown with little opportunity for anything else. Wheat yields are low in irrigated areas in the western 
basins, with an average of about 2 tons per ha (t/ha), and even lower in rainfed areas. The low 
yields are related to insecurity of water supply, which directly limits yields, and also provides a 
disincentive for farmers to invest in inputs. Currently, very little poppy is grown in the western 
basins and improving productivity of irrigated agriculture and enhancing livelihood opportunities will 
ensure poppy cultivation remains limited. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities  
6.  Ministry of Energy and Water. The Ministry of Energy and Water’s (MEW’s) Irrigation 
Department is responsible for irrigation development and managing the country’s water resources. 
Given the past 30 years of civil unrest, the capacity of the MEW is limited, especially in provinces 
and districts where few trained or experienced technical staff are available. As of mid-2005, the 
Irrigation Department in Herat had a technical staff of four engineers, all with limited experience 
and  training.  The  department  lacks  trained  administrative  and  management  staff,  has  little 
equipment such as computers or vehicles, and has essentially no operational capacity outside 
Herat  in  the  western  basins.  Rehabilitation  and  upgrading  (R&U)  of  irrigation  systems  and 
development of water resources in the western basins have tremendous potential to stimulate the 
local economy and improve rural livelihoods, yet this requires signification additional capacity and 
sound management to ensure sustainability and maximum development impact. 
 
7.  Irrigation Infrastructure. The irrigation systems of the western basins are in urgent need 
of assistance, with entire canal networks requiring major R&U due to decades of civil unrest that 
have  impeded  routine  maintenance  and  repair.  The  deterioration  of  system  infrastructure  is 
exacerbated  by  the  area’s  flood  hydrology,  which  creates  a  constant  need  to  protect  and 
rehabilitate canal intakes, canals, and adjacent farmland against floods, erosion, and sediment 
deposition.  Because  of  the  traditional  nature  of  the  irrigation  systems,  few  modern  control 
structures exist, and current water distribution is achieved through rudimentary diversion structures 
that are often temporary and makeshift leading to inefficiencies. These irrigation systems can be 
rationalized to operate much more efficiently and to increase the irrigated area. Canal intakes can 
be upgraded for greater capture of low season flows and to prevent flood damage and sediment 
deposition. As a result of unreliable supply of water and the degraded condition of irrigation 
systems, cropping intensity in the western basins was only 40% at the end of the severe drought 
from 1999 to 2001. R&U of the systems, especially the intakes, will provide more reliable water 
supply,  increase  conveyance  efficiency,  and  improve  water  control  and  management,  thus 
increasing  irrigation  intensity,  improving  yields  for  first  season  crops,  and  providing  more 
opportunities for second season and perennial crops. About 30 primary irrigation systems exist in 
the lower Hari Rud River Basin with an average size of about 2,000 ha and many smaller schemes 
are found throughout the basin. 
 
8.  Traditional Irrigation Management. Traditional irrigation systems (all surface irrigation in 
the western basins is traditional) comprise over 80% of the irrigated area in Afghanistan and 
communities continue to be responsible for management, and operation and maintenance (O&M). 
Local communities select mirabs3 who manage the system, water distribution, and O&M with the 
support of community labor. Mirabs may serve for many years and the position may be passed 
from generation to generation. A hierarchy usually exists with one senior mirab responsible for the

entire irrigation system and other lower-level mirabs responsible for distributaries and minor canals. 
The role of the mirab may require full-time service for a large portion of the year, with mirabs 
usually receiving an in-kind fee from each year’s harvest. The mirabs receive no formal assistance 
from  the  Government,  although  they  may  collaborate  with  the  Irrigation  Department  or  other 
authorities on an ad-hoc basis to execute O&M or other rehabilitation projects. The financial and 
other resources at their disposal are meager. O&M is provided by community labor with hundreds 
or thousands of men in labor gangs undertaking annual irrigation system maintenance. Although 
this management system has worked well for generations, the extremely dilapidated condition of 
the irrigation systems necessitates additional resources and technical support to the mirabs and 
communities  in  order  to  (i)  return  the  systems  to  good  operating  condition  to  ensure  that 
communities can sustain their performance, and (ii) enhance their performance for more productive 
irrigated agriculture. Women play no direct role in irrigated agriculture and have very limited control 
over water or other productive resources due to the conservative patriarchal society. Women are 
traditionally consigned to household tasks and may be involved with home gardens or livestock 
activities. 
 
9.  The mirabs would benefit from training in areas of basic engineering to support O&M, 
improved  water  management,  and  introduction  of  more  efficient  irrigation  technologies  and 
methods.  Strengthening  the  mirabs  by  improving  accountability  and  transparency,  developing 
business and financial management capacity, and establishing their legal status will help them to 
mobilize additional resources and to become more effective in their tasks. However, the mirabs 
have provided robust irrigation management and O&M for centuries, and any proposed technical or 
institutional changes to traditional irrigation systems must explicitly recognize and accommodate 
the mirab system to ensure success. 
 
10.  Water Resources Management. The policy framework for integrated water resources 
management (IWRM) and irrigation is being developed. The Strategic Framework for the Water 
Sector was finalized in May 2004 and approved by the Cabinet; it is consistent with the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) water policy.4 In 2004, the Government also issued water resources and 
irrigation policies. The objective of the irrigation policy is to develop and manage irrigation systems 
cost-effectively;  ensure  technical,  social,  institutional,  and  environmental  sustainability;  and 
promote user participation in local water management to ensure an overall increase in production 
and productivity of agriculture. MEW is currently drafting a revised water law that will be approved 
in  2006.  Although  the  policy  framework  is  being  established  with  external  funding  support, 
developing implementation arrangements and the capacity, especially at the regional level, to 
apply the policies pose a challenge. MEW staff currently do not have adequate skills, and basic 
hydrological data has not been collected for the past 25 years.5 The Irrigation Department has 
dynamic leadership and is committed to capacity development and modern water management; 
however, establishing effective water management institutions requires a long-term commitment. 
 
11.  River Basin Management. Developing optimum approaches to river basin management is 
important to maximize investment benefits and assess equity trade-offs. Water allocation options 
need to be evaluated and agreements reached regarding the sharing of water among irrigation 
schemes and water users. MEW has committed to develop river basin authorities (RBAs) to 
manage Afghanistan’s water resources. Adopting a river basin approach is essential for the Hari 
Rud River Basin due to substantial investments, including development of the Salma Dam being

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The Project will improve rural livelihoods through strengthened IWRM, improved irrigation 
service  delivery,  and  enhanced  agricultural  practices  to  increase  the  productivity  of  irrigated 
agriculture in the western basins of Afghanistan. The primary project impacts include (i) improved 
IWRM  and  water  management,  (ii)  R&U  and  development  of  irrigation  and  water  resources 
infrastructure,  (iii)  support  for  improved  agricultural  productivity  and  rural  livelihoods,  and  (iv) 
capacity  development  and  strengthened  institutional  frameworks  for  IWRM  and  irrigated 
agriculture.  The  Project  has  four  components:  (i)  IWRM,  (ii)  water  resources  and  irrigation 
development, (iii) agriculture and livelihood services, and (iv) capacity development and project 
management.  
 
B.  Outputs 
1.  Integrated Water Resources Management  
15.  Improving IWRM in the Hari Rud River Basin is critical to its development due to the 
importance of water to basin livelihoods, deficiencies in data to support decision making, and lack 
of existing capacity for effective management. The IWRM component has three subcomponents: (i) 
technical investigations and studies, (ii) water allocation and planning, and (iii) IWRM institutional 
and capacity development.13 
 
16.  Technical Investigations and Studies. Technical activities in support of IWRM and basin 
management will include (i) surface water investigations, (ii) groundwater investigations, and (iii) 
establishment of basin management information systems. The Project will review ongoing hydro-
meteorological programs to identify additional data requirements for improved basin management 
and project implementation. It will develop and apply methodologies and procedures to prepare 
inventories of surface water sources and their catchments, abstractions from the Hari Rud River 
Basin, and irrigated areas to provide the basis for the basin simulation modeling. The Project will 
provide equipment and establish monitoring procedures for surface water quality consistent with 
international protocols and standards. 
 
17.  The Project will establish a groundwater exploration and monitoring network based on an 
inventory of existing groundwater wells, springs, and karez;14 and by installing monitoring wells 
throughout the Hari Rud River Basin. This will support development of an integrated groundwater 
and surface water model for assessing sustainable groundwater yields and conjunctive use and to 
maintain karez and spring flows. Alternative irrigation technologies such as drip, sprinkler, and 
plastic piping will be installed on plots associated with monitoring wells and at commercial farms to 
demonstrate water-efficient irrigation options. 
 
18.  The Project will support establishment of information systems to manage technical and 
administrative  data  for  management  of  basin  resources  (including  surface  and  groundwater). 
Geographic information system activities started during project preparation will be expanded to 
integrate basin information including (i) water resources infrastructure, (ii) surface and groundwater 
information,  (iii)  environmental  data,  and  (iv)  land-use  data.  This  will  support  watershed

2.  Water Resources and Irrigation Development 
22.  The Project will support R&U of irrigation, strengthening of irrigation service delivery and 
accountability consistent with ADB’s water policy (footnote 4), and development of water resources 
through four subcomponents: (i) irrigation R&U in the Hari Rud River Basin, (ii) irrigation R&U in the 
Murghab Basin, (iii) water resources development, and (iv) mirab development and O&M. The 
Project will ensure that traditional allocations and distribution methods are preserved during the 
R&U unless otherwise supported by the community. R&U and development of all subprojects will 
be  fully  participatory  with  mirabs  and  the  community  involved  in  the  identification,  design, 
management, and O&M of the civil works. The community will provide in-kind contribution to 
subprojects as well as agree to abstain from poppy cultivation and to sustain O&M. Women will be 
consulted and confirm the positioning and design of nonirrigation infrastructure such as bridges. 
Due to Afghanistan’s limited capacity, evolving policy framework, and weak investment planning, 
an ADB sector loan is not possible. However, given the number of irrigation schemes requiring 
R&U in the western basins and the need for flexibility with project implementation in Afghanistan, a 
sector-like approach will be used for subproject selection based on criteria with an indicative 
investment plan to be refined during the Project (Appendix 5). 
 
23.  Irrigation  R&U  in  the  Hari  Rud  River  Basin.  The  subprojects  for  irrigation  schemes 
prepared during the project preparatory TA provide a representative sample of the Project’s R&U

(i) improved intakes for greater capture efficiency, (ii) rehabilitated and improved control structures,

and rationalization, (viii) river training and bank protection, (ix) vehicle and pedestrian bridges and 
improved access to canals for nonirrigation water needs, and (x) drainage.

exist. The Project will work with mirabs and communities to demonstrate options to enhance 
system  performance  including  (i)  improved  intakes,  control  structures,  and  canal  profiles;  (ii) 
enhanced flexibility of irrigation deliveries to meet demand; and (iii) better distribution and rotation 
scheduling. The Project will demonstrate the benefits of improved operational options while training 
mirabs and communities, so they can adopt and benefit from new technologies and management 
techniques. However, community acceptance is necessary before any technical or management 
changes  will  be  undertaken  through  the  Project.  Long-term  capacity  development  will  also

D.  Special Features 
38.  Integrated Basin Approach. The Project takes an integrated approach. Components 1, 2, 
and 3, work together to improve water management from the basin to the farm by (i) creating an 
improved knowledge base for optimal resource management, (ii) improving technical options and 
infrastructure, and (iii) strengthening management and institutional frameworks at all levels. The 
Project  addresses  management  of  surface  water,  groundwater,  and  water  quality  to  ensure 
sustainable development. The integrated approach will achieve higher agricultural productivity, 
improved water use efficiency and distribution equity, and sustainable water resource utilization.  
 
39.  Capacity Building and Effective Implementation. Capacity building is integral to achieve 
and sustain project outcomes and is essential to ensure Afghanistan’s development. The Project 
explicitly addresses capacity development with both formal and informal training, TA, and provision 
of  necessary  resources  for  project  stakeholders.  However  effective  capacity  development  of 
technical skills to implement the Project will take time, and given that project activities must 
commence upon loan effectiveness to ensure that early benefits are realized, resources will initially 
need to be contracted locally and/or regionally to support technical services and implementation.

These locally or regionally procured services will be phased out as capacity develops and MEW 
can assume a greater share of project responsibilities.

sustainability of the Government payroll and security expenditures, and highlighted the importance 
of continued assistance from external funding agencies.20 The ADF lending terms from the ADB 
Board of Directors, while generous, are not sufficient for sustainable development of Afghanistan.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits  
57.  Economic and Financial Benefits. The economic benefits of the Project will result from 
the irrigation system R&U investments to improve yields, expand irrigated areas, and increase 
cropping intensity. The economic returns are based on the analysis of 3 irrigation R&U subprojects 
prepared under the TA. The economic internal rates of return (EIRR) of the irrigation diversion 
schemes analyzed over 20 years are 12%, 20%, and 22% when all project management costs are 
included.26 The benefits for the irrigation schemes are based purely on productivity increases and 
do not include benefits of improved mobility and market access from bridges and flood protection 
of canals.27 The assumed benefits from the irrigation R&U and agricultural support services include 
an increase in wheat yields of about 40% from low baseline yields of 2.0 t/ha to about 2.8 t/ha.28 
The area of horticultural activities increased from a low base of about 5% cropping intensity to 
about 20% cropping intensity with yield increases of around 20%. Based on the subprojects 
prepared, the assumed cost was about $650/ha for the R&U works, agricultural support services, 
and mirab development assistance. The Project will complete R&U of about 45,000 ha in the Hari 
Rud River Basin, 10,000 ha in the Murghab Basin, and an additional 6,500 ha equivalent in water 
resources development. The EIRR of the overall Project is 17%.29 
 
58.  Household budgets were prepared for various incomes groups for the subprojects. In the 
Jui Nau Canal subproject, the smallest farmers (assumed 0.8 ha landholding) realized an increase 
in net income of $234 or a 117% rise in household earnings. In many cases, much of the net 
increase  will  be  consumed,  thus  improving  food  security  and  nutrition  (Appendix  10).  The 
incremental recurrent costs for O&M are estimated to be about $2.6/ha per year. This represents 
about a 25% increase in the current community O&M contribution. Even for poor farmers, this 
amount lies well within their ability to pay to ensure financial sustainability and cost recovery. Given 
the average family size of seven and average landholding (or area farmed by sharecroppers) at 1

B.  Social and Other Benefits and Impacts 
59.  Social Impacts. In the districts where project preparation took place, approximately 54% of 
the population classed themselves as very poor, 30% as poor, 16% as well-off, and none as rich. 
Given that average landholdings are less than 1 ha and up to 30% of the population is landless and 
many sharecrop, the Project will have a large impact on reducing poverty and improving food 
security. For some farmers, the Project will provide increased opportunities for perennial crops, 
second season vegetables, and rice cultivation with substantial income impacts. The shift from 
grain production to higher value cropping will be consistent with expected changes in food demand 
and  consumption.  The  improvement  and  change  in  production  will  be  achieved  through  the 
irrigation R&U, and through increasing the capacity of farmers, which will allow them to make better 
production decisions as irrigated agriculture continues to develop and intensify in the western 
basins.  Marginalized  members  of  society  will  benefit  through  labor  opportunities  provided  by 
second season cropping; and the income-generating opportunities in component 3 are targeted 
specifically at the women and the landless.  
 
60.  IWRM and Improved Water Use Efficiency. The Project will support (i) increased water 
use efficiency in terms of productivity and returns per unit volume of water, (ii) development of 
improved intakes and capture efficiency for improved water supply, and (iii) greater efficiency and 
equity  of  water  distribution  within  irrigation  systems.  Physical  improvements  to  the  irrigation 
systems will be augmented by institutional strengthening through the RBA at the basin level and 
through stronger mirabs and MEW for better management and O&M at the system level. Even 
though the Project does not quantify financial or economic benefits from the IWRM component, it 
will  provide  long-term  benefits  from  equitably  and  efficiently  managing  and  allocating  surface 
water. Sustainable groundwater management will be especially important as pumped water use 
will continue to grow, and water quality concerns will increase with population and economic 
growth. In an arid environment where water is essential to livelihoods, the IWRM activities will be 
absolutely essential to maintain and sustain regional economic growth. 
 
61.  Resettlement. Project interventions will primarily consist of R&U of traditional irrigation 
systems and small water resources development subprojects. Although a resettlement framework 
was developed, the subprojects prepared during the TA did not indicate that resettlement activities 
would be necessary. The most likely resettlement actions will be temporary compensation during 
construction; however, mirabs and communities will be consulted extensively during subproject 
preparation to develop a construction plan that minimizes disruptions. The majority of construction 
activities will be executed when the irrigation systems are not in use. A resettlement framework 
was prepared and in the event of resettlement impacts, resettlement plans will be prepared in 
accordance  with  the  resettlement  framework.  Procedures  and  consultant  support  to  develop 
resettlement plans are provided through the Project and will be in place 8 months after loan 
effectiveness. Any necessary resettlement activities will include external monitoring (Appendix 11, 
and Supplementary Appendix C). 
 
62.  Environmental Impacts. Environmental impacts from the Project are not anticipated to be 
significant and should not impact downstream users. The TA prepared an initial environmental 
examination (IEE) for each of the three subprojects and for the entire Project (Appendix 12 and 
Supplementary Appendix D). The IEE for the subprojects did not predict impacts of significance 
either during R&U or after subproject completion. The IEE for the entire Project concluded that all 
the components should provide environmental benefits in the medium- to long-term except for 
R&U, which is not anticipated to create any negative impacts. The IEE for the Jui Nau canal 
subproject, along with the environmental assessment review procedures, provide an environmental 
framework to guide the PMU and the National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA), which will

subprojects and mitigating measures implemented if needed. An environmental monitoring plan will

63.  Capacity Development. Although no quantified economic benefits or costs are attributed 
to capacity development, it will have a significant impact in terms of sustainability of project benefits

internationally are expected to continue the R&U activities as well as contribute to development of 
new  irrigation.  Mirabs,  ministry  staff,  and  farmers  trained  under  the  Project  will  provide  a 
permanent resource to foster agricultural and economic growth in the western basins. Professional 
and technical MEW staff having been trained, and gaining experience under the Project, will also 
serve as a core of institutional expertise benefiting water resource development and management 
activities throughout Afghanistan in the years to come. 
 
C.  Risks 
64.  Security.  The  overall  political  and  security  situation  remains  unsettled  in  Afghanistan 
although the western region is one of the most secure areas in the country. Careful monitoring and 
coordination with Government authorities and the United Nations will be needed. ADB’s ongoing 
Security of ADB Financed Projects TA30 will provide advice to ensure a safe work environment for 
on-site personnel. Under the prevailing conditions, however, the security risks cannot be mitigated 
completely, and minor delays in project implementation may be inevitable despite risk-mitigating 
measures should security problems arise. 
 
65.  Contracting of Civil Works. Due to the long period of civil unrest and stagnation of 
construction in the project area, a risk exists that the capacity of local contractors is inadequate to 
implement the project civil works within the time frame and costs and to required quality standards. 
The Project will use a variety of contracting methods including ICB for large contract packages to 
ensure international or regional contractors with experience are able to complete a large number of 
works in a timely manner and ensuring quality. The larger international contractor will subcontract 
portions of the work to local contractors thus developing their capacity through project experience. 
The Project will also use local contractors, selected through LCB, and employing the following 
safeguards:  (i)  training  for  contractors  on  best  practice  and  ADB  procedures;  (ii)  strict 
prequalification criteria with a test period; and (iii) contracts with penalties for late performance that 
will  be  enforced.  Local  contracting  capacity  is  expected  to  become  sufficient  as  the  Project 
develops.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Afghanistan: 
Water resources and irrigated agriculture are fundamental to the rural sector, poverty reduction, and the national 
economy in Afghanistan. Agriculture makes up about 50% and 60% of Afghanistan's gross domestic product (GDP) 
and employs about 80% of the population. Irrigated Agriculture is responsible for up to 80% of all agricultural 
production in some years. Afghanistan has about 2.5–3.0 million hectares (ha) of agricultural land with some irrigation 
facilities out of the total arable area of about 8 million ha.1 However, much of this land receives only intermittent 
irrigation and in some years may receive no irrigation at all due to poor condition of systems and variable rainfall. The 
National Vulnerability Survey indicated that lack of irrigation water was the number one constraint to agriculture across 
the county at 31%.2 Rainfed agriculture takes place on about 4.5–5.0 million ha but is unreliable for productivity due to 
variability in rainfall including recurrent drought. 
 
Until 2003, Afghanistan had not been self-sufficient in cereal production since 1976. From 1978 though the 1980s, 
production steadily fell due to civil unrest and associated deterioration of the agricultural sector and food insecurity 
was widespread. In 1990, production was only 60% of previous levels, yet the sector recovered throughout the 1990s 
due to improved security and better rainfall. However, a chronic drought from 1999 to 2001 devastated the agricultural 
sector with a near total failure of rainfed farming. Many traditionally irrigated lands were deprived of water, which 
destroyed long-standing orchards and vineyard in many areas. Livestock was significantly impacted with substantially 
reduced herds with a corresponding drop in rural assets and wealth, especially affecting the landless and nomadic 
herdsmen. By 2004, 70% of all rural households had still not fully recovered income or asset losses from the drought 
from 1999 to 2001. As a drought coping strategy, 40% of rural families decreased food consumption from levels that 
were  already  deficient  for  adequate  nutrition,  and  many  were  forced  to  sell  land  for  income  rendering  them 
permanently worse off and more prone to poverty. 
 
Increased security and better rains in 2002 and 2003 improved agricultural performance with a record cereal harvest 
of about 5.4 million tons in 2003. Favorable conditions benefited other crops as well as livestock, and the strong 
recovery of the agricultural sector was driving economic growth. In 2004, however, another deficit rainfall year 
brought about drought conditions that were estimated to have caused a 20–25% decline in cereal production. 
Because of the drought conditions, an estimated 16% GDP growth for 2003–04 was revised downwards to 8%, and 
an additional 2.5 million Afghans were faced with food insecurity. The recurrent droughts are not only detrimental to 
agricultural production but seriously impact drinking water supplies and health in many rural communities. To ensure 
food security, reduce rural poverty, and ensure national economic growth, development of water resources and 
improving irrigated agriculture are essential since the productivity and reliability of rainfed farming does not provide a 
sustainable basis to achieve these. 
 
In December 2001, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), and World 
Bank jointly undertook a preliminary needs assessment study of various sectors. The assessment recognized the 
need for a comprehensive approach to water resources management, irrigation, and ensuring women and vulnerable 
groups benefit from rural recovery initiatives.3 The National Development Framework4 was finalized by the Afghanistan 
Interim Administration in April 2002. Its development strategy is based on three pillars: (i) humanitarian and human 
and social capital, (ii) physical reconstruction and natural resources including emphasis on water resources, and (iii) 
private sector development. In March 2004, Securing Afghanistan’s Future was formulated jointly between the 
Government of Afghanistan, ADB, United Nations Assistance Mission to Afghanistan, UNDP, and World Bank for an 
international conference held in Berlin. This document set out the plans for the future of Afghanistan over the coming 
10–20 years, in line with the Afghanistan National Development Framework, including emphasis on development of 
water resources and irrigation infrastructure and associated natural resource management, particularly the need for a 
comprehensive approach to water management through basin management. The Afghanistan National Development 
Strategy  that  is  currently  under  preparation  also  highlights  the  development  of  water  resources  and  irrigated

development strategies have all linked the importance of infrastructure development and strengthening institutional

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Women in Afghanistan play a far less prominent role to males in social and economic decision making. They have 
been traditionally confined to household activities including taking care of children, home gardens, and some livestock 
activities. Women’s awareness of the role and function of water management is very limited, and they do not see 
themselves as playing a part in water management decision making. Male stakeholders have limited perception of the 
relevance of women’s involvement in agricultural activities or natural resource use. Women landowners are not 
normally involved in making decisions concerning use of their land, nor accessing revenues resulting from use of that 
land. Women landowners are not normally included in interactions with external agencies. Women often do not 
participate in activity discussions as social restrictions prevent them from sitting and discussing matters with men. 
Women cannot be grouped as a single element, but will have different stakeholder perspectives as much as men. 
Institutional policies and practices constrain women’s participation in project activities and are not supportive of their 
role in the agriculture sector. Women experience multiple time constraints due to multiple task responsibilities in 
different ways than men, thus having implications for participation. Both men and women feel women need more 
support than they are currently receiving in order to successfully participate in natural resource management activities.

SECTOR AND SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  Water resources management and irrigated agriculture are critical to the well-being of the 
rural sector, poverty reduction, and the national economy. Irrigated agriculture produces up to 80% 
of agricultural output, makes up 50–60% of the total national economy, and employs around 80% 
of the population. Deficit rainfall in 2004 had a devastating impact on the economy when the 
expected 16% annual gross domestic product growth was revised downward to 8% and 2.5 million 
Afghans were faced with food insecurity. In the National Vulnerability Risk Assessment, farmers 
throughout the country cited lack of irrigation water as the number one constraint to agriculture.1 
Agriculture uses 95% of developed water supplies, thus improvement of irrigated agriculture and 
strengthening of water resources management must be pursued in parallel to sustain Afghanistan’s 
economic growth and address rural poverty. 
 
2.  The Western Basins. Badghis, Ghowr, and Herat provinces comprise the western basins. 
With the exception of Herat City, the second largest city in Afghanistan, most of the districts in the 
western  basins  are  nearly  100%  rural.  The  area  has  about  2  million  people,  or  8%  of  the 
Afghanistan’s population, with Pashtuns and Tajiks being the most common ethnic groups. Up to 
30% of rural households are landless, the average farm size is no more than 1 hectare (ha), and 
increasing numbers of the poorest households are farming on marginal land and in washes where 
risk of drought and floods is high. These poorest households are highly vulnerable to livelihood 
shocks and thus have the most limited options to resist opium poppy cultivation in desperate times. 
Population growth will continue at nearly 2% per annum over the next 10 years; the area is a home 
to many returning refugees. Yet in spite of the challenges facing the western basins, the area has 
some of the greatest potential for economic growth through intensification of irrigated agriculture 
and related services and industries. 
 
3.  The Hari Rud and Murghab rivers are the largest in western Afghanistan; together their 
basins cover 78,000 square kilometers (km) (over 12% of Afghanistan). They provide 3 billion cubic 
meters of annual water runoff, split almost equally between the two basins, although the Hari Rud 
River  Basin  is  far  more  developed.  The  rivers  flow  west  from  Afghanistan  and  drain  into 
Turkmenistan, with the Hari Rud first passing along the border with Iran. The majority of runoff 
comes from snowmelt with high flood flows from March to June and very low flows from August to 
February. Since most irrigation systems are river diversions, this means that discharge is excess in 
the spring and deficit in the summer to meet crop water requirements, and farmers have adapted 
their irrigation and agricultural practices to this flood-flow water regime. The Salma Dam, which is a 
proposed  multipurpose  facility  to  be  constructed  160  km  east  of  Herat  and  financed  by  the 
Government of India, should mitigate spring floods and enhance dry season flows.

valleys with seven provinces providing nearly one third the total irrigated area. Total irrigated area 
is  about  2.5–3.0  million  ha,  although  in  many  years  many  areas  may  only  have  intermittent 
irrigation.2 The country has five basic types of irrigation systems: (i) arhad or Persian wheel (about

6.  Traditional Irrigation Systems. Traditional irrigation systems are the most common type 
of irrigation system in Afghanistan and are based on gravity surface water diversion systems or 
spring fed.5 They generally have few formal control structures and use earthen canals that rely on 
brush, log, mud, stone, and some masonry water control structures. Intake structures are usually 
not engineered or permanent, and rely on brush, logs, rock, and makeshift gabions. Given the 
annual flood hydrology and the fact that river channels often shift laterally and have lowering bed 
levels, intake structures need to be rebuilt on a frequent basis. Large traditional systems may 
supply thousands of hectares and have hundreds of kilometers of canals. In general, the size of 
the traditional irrigation systems increases as one moves down the river valleys and out into the 
plains since the topography is more favorable for development, the land is more fertile, and flows 
generally larger. Larger systems have main, secondary, and smaller canals; may include numerous 
villages in their command area; and may supply water for domestic use, livestock, and municipal 
supply. Average irrigation efficiency is considered to be about 25–30% due to high conveyance 
losses in traditional schemes and high on-farm distribution losses due to poor command area 
development.

western basins; the lower Hari Rud River Basin contains nearly 10% of the country’s functional

developed some canals over 500 years ago with a few able to irrigate up to 5000–10,000 ha. The 
systems have sophisticated water allocation practices based on irrigated area and location within the 
canal command. The western basins have 302,000 ha of irrigation, of which 173,000 ha (57%) are 
intensively irrigated and of this 109,000 ha (63% of intensive irrigation) are found in the lower Hari 
Rud River Basin (Herat Province) (Table A3). Most of the intermittent irrigated lands were also in the 
Hari Rud River Basin (62%) with the majority also in the lower Hari Rud River Basin. The existing

8.  Condition of Irrigation Infrastructure. About one third of Afghanistan's villages were 
damaged or destroyed during the first 10 years of war (1979/89), and the impact on irrigation

exodus of farmers and dereliction of operation and maintenance (O&M). After the war in the 1990s,

complex schemes with intakes from bigger rivers, greater problems were encountered including 
complete sedimentation of larger canals and dilapidation of major structures and canals.6 An 
estimated 10% of systems were directly affected by combat, while another 40%, particularly large-

river intakes, rationalization of canal networks, improved structures for water control and regulation, 
improved cross drainage, canal protection, and other improvements consistent with modern design

rise of local commanders in the rural power vacuum created after the fall of the Taliban along with

strong as witnessed by the thousands of laborers participating in canal maintenance during 2004

irrigated  land),  and  historically  specific  taxes  were  paid  on  paikal  land.  The  taxes  paid

several centuries commensurate with the irrigation systems. Strict adherence to the traditional 
allocation system has weakened in some cases, and even when the paikal system is adhered to it 
is still imprecise. However, all mirabs and irrigated landholders are aware of the system and at 
least superficially acknowledge the system and their particular paikal allocations and rotations. 
Most importantly, most Afghan farmers understand how the system works and irrigate with the 
expectation of a limited allocation. 
 
2.  Agriculture 
15.  Agriculture has always been vital to the national economy and plays a central role in 
Afghanistan’s redevelopment efforts and poverty reduction. Agriculture, however, suffered during 
the last 25 years due to deterioration of supporting infrastructure, including irrigation and prolonged 
droughts. Afghans are assiduous farmers, and with recent stability complemented by better rains, 
the agriculture sector is rebounding. Farmers have access to improved seed as well as fertilizer 
where  water  supplies  are  reliable;  however,  inadequate  knowledge  of  improved  agricultural 
production processes, lack of assured and timely irrigation, weak institutional capacity of the 
private and public sectors, and lack of credit and access to markets pose constraints in some 
locations. The Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Husbandry, and Food (MAAHF) is the Government 
agency responsible for agricultural development. ADB’s Agriculture Sector Program loan11 provides 
guiding policy principles that were discussed in detail with the Government and lays out a road 
map to sector reform and growth. 
 
16.  Agriculture in the Western Basins. Although a large ministry, MAAHF has weak capacity 
in Kabul and in the provinces. The MAAHF office in Herat does have a staff of over 400 employees 
including officers in the 16 districts of the province. However, the office has fewer than 100 
technical  staff  and  their  competence  is  low.  MAAHF  resources  to  support  extension  work, 
transport, or research are limited or nonexistent. Much of the support to MAAHF, including vehicles 
and equipment, has been provided by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations 
which has been operating in Afghanistan continually through the Taliban time. Nongovernment 
organizations also provide some agricultural support services. 
 
17.  The western basins, especially the Hari Rud River Basin, have an agricultural history dating 
back centuries with traditional irrigation. Agriculture is based on a wheat and opportunistic summer 
crop/fallow  rotation  with  increasing  importance  of  rice,  vegetables,  and  fruit  where  water  is

incremental  volume,  quality,  and  diversity  of  regional  and  national  production.  The  expected 
incremental annual demand for vegetables and potatoes is expected to exceed 30,000 tons by 
2015, which could be met locally through increased production from improved irrigation. Regional 
demand  for  an  incremental  90,000  tons  of  wheat  is  unlikely  to  be  fully  satisfied  from  local 
production,  so  increases  in  wheat  production  will  have  a  strong  local  market.  Some  of  the 
incremental productivity will be consumed within households and therefore help improve food 
security. Economic growth by 2015 is estimated to cause a 30% increase in per capita demand for 
food, which will strengthen demand for higher value crops. 
 
3.  Water Resources Management 
19.  Policy Framework. The Irrigation Department is responsible for integrated water resources 
management (IWRM), and the policy framework for IWRM and irrigated agriculture is emerging. 
The Strategic Framework for the Water Sector, approved by the Cabinet in May 2004, commits to 
the following six principles which is consistent with ADB’s Water Policy (i) decentralization of 
planning, development, and management of water resources to river basins; (ii) delivery of water 
services  by  autonomous  and  accountable  institutions;  (iii)  sustainable  water  use  within  a 
transparent policy framework; (iv) participatory and consultative processes; (v) a program of long-
term capacity building, budget support, and research; and (vi) equitable treatment of international 
waters. In accordance with these principles, the Government issued policies on water resources 
and irrigation during 2004. The specific objectives of the irrigation policy are “to develop and 
manage irrigation systems cost-effectively; ensure technical, social, institutional, and environmental 
sustainability; and promote user participation in local water management that can ensure overall 
increase in production and productivity of agriculture." Based on the principles found in the various 
policies, MEW is currently drafting a revised water law that was last amended in 1981. Although 
the policy framework is being established with external assistance, developing the implementation 
arrangements as well as the capacity (both human and technical) especially at the provincial and 
regional level to realize the policies poses a long-term challenge. 
 
20.  Groundwater.  Groundwater  falls  under  the  jurisdiction  of  the  Ministry  of  Mines  and 
Industry, and a groundwater management strategy is currently under preparation through ADB’s 
Agriculture Sector Program loan (footnote 9). However, applying and implementing the strategy in 
a particular groundwater basin and developing a management plan will require time and capacity. 
Initial assessments indicate that the Hari Rud River Basin has significant groundwater potential 
even though it has remained largely unexploited. Both shallow and deep wells are increasing in the 
area and this trend is expected to accelerate as incomes rise. Although offering tremendous 
opportunity, insufficient information exists regarding sustainable groundwater yields. Once this 
information  is  known,  a  basin  management  plan  can  be  developed  to  support  sustainable 
development of groundwater.

SUMMARY ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSES 
 
1.  The Western Basin Water Resources Management Project (the Project) will support the 
rehabilitation and upgrading (R&U) of traditional irrigation schemes under the Project and will 
benefit about 55,000 irrigable hectares (ha).1 The civil works will be combined with agricultural 
and livelihood services, and institutional strengthening for the mirabs (traditional community 
water managers), the Irrigation Department within Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW), and 
project participants. The Project will also include income-generating activities for women and the 
landless. The following analysis is based on the interventions proposed under the Project. 
 
2.  Project Costs. The total project financial cost is estimated at $87.6 million, including 
contingencies, taxes and duties, and interest during implementation. The base cost (excluding 
taxes and duties) for component 2, which includes irrigation R&U for the Hari Rud River Basin 
and Murghab River Basin, the water resources and development subcomponent, and mirab 
capacity development and operation and maintenance (O&M), is $52.7 million. The assumed 
investment costs for irrigation R&U are about $565 per irrigable ha based on the estimated 
subproject R&U costs. The base cost for component 1, integrated water resources management 
is $7.9 million; component 3, agriculture and livelihood services $8.5 million; and component 4, 
capacity development and project management $8.6 million.  
 
3.  Integrated  Water  Resources  Management.  Although  quantifiable  benefits  are  not 
attributed to this component, the activities will provide support for surface and groundwater 
management  that  are  essential  for  long-term  development  and  economic  sustainability  of 
irrigated agriculture in the Hari Rud River Basin and Murghab River Basin. Improved surface 
water allocation will not only ensure maximum productivity, but also equity among upstream and 
downstream water users. 
 
4.  Capacity Development. Capacity development will help ensure long-term sustainability of 
project  benefits  and  help  Afghanistan’s  long-term  redevelopment;  however,  these  costs  are 
excluded from the project analysis. Improved capacity of MEW will facilitate further irrigation R&U in 
the region and throughout Afghanistan to extend project benefits. 
 
A.  Methodology and Main Assumptions 
 
5.  Economic and financial analyses were carried out for three core subprojects prepared 
under the project preparatory technical assistance (TA) to assess economic viability and the 
financial impact on households. Economic analysis of the overall Project is also presented. 
Sensitivity analysis on the subprojects and the Project as a whole were conducted. Farm 
budgets  for  various  wealth  groups  were  estimated  to  assess  project  impacts  on  farm 
households.  With-project  and  without-project  scenarios  were  simulated  to  determine  the 
incremental project benefits. 
 
6.  Costs. Project financial costs were estimated in afghanis (AFs) using prices prevailing in 
the first half of 2005, and expressed in constant prices over the project implementation period of 
7  years.  Financial  prices  were  derived  from  local  sources  and  include  taxes  and  duties.

values expressed in constant 2005 prices to exclude inflation; (iii) a standard conversion factor 
of 0.9 for nontraded goods and services; (iv) a shadow value of 0.6 for unskilled and agricultural 
labor to take account of the labor surplus in rural areas; (v) border parity pricing with standard 
methods to derive farm-gate input/output prices for major tradable commodities and goods; and

C.  The Jui Nau Canal Irrigation Scheme 
 
11.  Subproject Overview. The Jui Nau is typical of the larger irrigation systems in the lower 
Hari Rud River Basin and provides an excellent example of the type and range of R&U activities 
to be executed under the Project. The Jui Nau main canal is 32 km and has five branch canals 
that vary in length from 2.2 to 8.5 km for a total length of 22 km. All of the system’s canals are 
severely degraded and have poor profiles. The main canal has 101 discharge points; 45 occur 
at 17 major bifurcations, which account for nearly 70% of total discharge. The condition of 
discharge points is very poor with need for R&U of structure and improved design. In some 
cases, the downstream sections and adjacent banks are severely undercut and eroded. Major 
structures in the system include (i) a main canal 1.5 km inverted siphon; (ii) a 25 meter (m) 
aqueduct where failure is imminent; (iii) two flood spillways; and (iv) 84 foot and vehicle bridges 
that cross the main canal and vary widely in dimension, construction, and condition. The canal 
provides domestic and livestock water supply; however, these uses are not included in the 
analysis.

only about 5,200 ha are irrigable, and usually about 3,300 ha are irrigated for a spring wheat

$1.8 million: (i) 45% for canal R&U, (ii) 23% to protect the canal network from flood damage, (iii) 
14% for upgrading intakes, (iv) 10% for bridges, and (v) 8% for R&U of minor and major control 
and conveyance structures. The cost is $355 per ha of R&U based on the 5,200 ha of irrigable

agricultural support service, livelihood service, and income-generating activities, and training for 
the farmers and the mirabs to accompany the irrigation R&U.5

The  involuntary  resettlement  policy  objectives  are  (i)  to  avoid  involuntary  resettlement

1.  Afghan Land Acquisition Law of 2000 
2.  The Islamic Republic of Afghanistan (the Government) currently has no formal national 
compensation and resettlement policy in place. The current policy approach is reflected in the 
Constitution of Afghanistan 2004 and the Land Acquisition Law of 2000. This law provides that land 
acquisition for public use will only occur with prior and fair replacement at current market rates upon 
approval by the Cabinet. Part 2 of the law prescribes that replacements will be provided for (i) land 
cost, (ii) cost of all buildings on the land, (iii) cost of fruit trees, and (iv) other valuable plants on the 
land. It also provides that at the landowner’s option, cropland of a similar value, and a house of 
suitable standards may be provided instead of monetary compensation. A further article provides 
for compensation to be paid for the input costs of unharvested crops. The law requires notification 
of amounts of compensation to be made 3 months in advance. This allows time for those affected 
to dispute any amount to a compensation committee (CC), which has been sanctioned by the 
Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW), or to follow the complaints and disputes procedures outlined 
here. 
 
3.  Article  10  of  Land  Acquisition  Law  provides  for  the  compensation  for  all  land  to  be 
determined by the Cabinet, taking into account land quality and location, and this responsibility can 
be delegated to a ministry. In the past, this has been implemented by the Cabinet setting a range of 
compensation levels for different classes and locations of land with the CC being left to decide 
actual amounts for each individual parcel. Article 11 provides for the assessment of costs (not 
values) of buildings for compensation purposes to be based on a table of building prices to be 
produced by the local authority. Landowners are permitted to salvage and remove materials from 
buildings in addition to being paid compensation or being supplied with replacement land and 
housing. The replacement costs of fruit trees are to be decided by the local authority and the 
Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Husbandry, and Food (MAAHF).

compensation for temporary use of land, yet the law does not appear to preclude the Government 
from recognizing and making compensation or rehabilitation payments for additional eligibilities.

paid to squatters or those without legal ownership documentation. However, it does not define legal 
ownership documents. In Afghanistan, unregistered written deeds of sale and purchase of land 
have been the most common form of ownership documentation for over 50 years and have come to

3.  The Jui Nau subproject is focused on the R&U of the Jui Nau irrigation system, and works 
should be completed by year 3 of the Project. The Jui Nau is typical of the larger irrigation systems 
in the lower Hari Rud in terms of water supply and rehabilitation issues, and serves as an example 
of the type and range of rehabilitation measures required for these systems. It is located close to 
heart city. The principal objective of the subproject is the improvement of water availability, efficiency 
of use, and equity of distribution for improved agricultural productivity. It comprises two principle 
elements: (i) development of canal infrastructure and associated system management, and (ii) 
provision of agricultural and livelihood services. In addition to improved water management an 
additional benefit is that by rehabilitating permanent structures, operation and maintenance costs 
will be reduced. The area involves 7,000 plus stakeholder households with an average of seven 
people per family. Key features of the subproject are summarized in Table A12.1. 
 
4.  General Criteria. The selection criteria for subprojects evolved during the course of the

right banks as well as in the upper and lower reaches of the lower Hari Rud; (iii) systems that can 
demonstrate a range of irrigation and water resource works (flood protection, etc.), and associated
