Appendix 12  57
C.  Description of the Environment 
6.  Primary  data  was  collected  by  personal  observation  of  the  river,  intakes,  canals,  and 
structures and of the areas surrounding the subproject area. Observations in the field were made 
with international consultants, national consultants, and Government officials in order that a range of 
opinions could be obtained. Primary data was also collected from reports and field work of other TA 
consultants. Secondary data was obtained from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United 
Nations library in Kabul, which serves as the library for MEW. Secondary data was also obtained 
from aid agency reports, nongovernment organization (NGO) reports, and the internet. Anecdotal 
data was provided through consultations and interviews with farmers, Government officials, NGO 
staff, and stakeholders. 
 
7.  The lower Hari Rud River Basin surrounding the subproject area is relatively barren with little 
vegetation outside the subproject area. Although it has low rainfall, erosion exists in some areas 
because the hillsides are almost bare of vegetation and the numerous washes (intermittent, flash 
flood,  streams)  erode  the  hillsides.  High  population  growth  combined  with  high  poverty  is 
accelerating soil erosion, biodiversity loss, water pollution, and dust storms. The fuel crisis in the 
subproject area has resulted in people not only cutting trees and shrubs but in digging out the root 
systems so that there is no regrowth. The subproject area has been farmed for over 300 years.  
 
8.  Except for summer sand and dust storms, the air quality is good. The climate is arid, with 
cold winters and hot, dry summers. The average rainfall at Herat is estimated to be about 310 
millimeters. The main source of surface and groundwater in the basin is snow melt, which is spread 
over about 2 months (February/March–April). The flow in the Hari Rud and Murghab rivers is 
sufficient to sustain irrigation from February through mid-June and sometimes into later months in a 
good precipitation year.  
 
9.  Elevations within the subproject area average about 1,000 meters mean sea level with 
relatively even relief after being irrigated for over 300 years. The subproject’s landform is primarily 
river valley where the soils are deep silt loams and fine sandy loams underlain by conglomerate or 
gravel. In depressions or in areas where drainage is impeded and a high water table occurs, salinity 
problems may occur but none were observed. Soils are low in available phosphate, nitrogen, and 
organic matter. The subproject area is geologically and seismologically stable. 
 
10.  Biodiversity is very limited after years of conflict and severe drought, with few visible species. 
Within the Jui Nau irrigation system, trees growing around homes and along the canals and rivers, 
provide scattered vegetation clumps supporting some habitat for wildlife. More trees will be planted 
as wind breaks to minimize sand and dust storms.   
 
11.  No mineral development or tourism facilities are within the subproject area. Outside of Herat, 
there is no electricity grid. Health services are sparse, with a doctor to people ratio of 1/6,637 in 
Herat. The subproject area has no protected areas, or cultural or historical sites. All parts of the Jui 
Nau system are away from the historic city of Herat. Recently, urban expansion has encroached on 
some of the lower reaches of the main canal. Some ruins of water cisterns and bathhouses are 
about 150 to 300 meters south of this portion of the main canal. These ruins are not within the 
subproject area. However, to ensure that no buried ruins are within the construction zone, the 
project design requires that prior to construction an archeological reconnaissance be made. All 
potential environmental impacts are positive. Mobility for people and animals will be improved in the 
subproject through the improvement of bridges.

58  Appendix 12 
D.  Forecasting Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
12.  The methodology for screening subproject activities by implementation activity was done in 
consultation with the National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA) professionals. Potential 
impacts were initially assessed using the checklist provided for irrigation projects in the ADB 
Environmental Guidelines for Selected Agricultural and Natural Resources Development Projects 
(Supplementary Appendix D). While conducting the public consultations, the NEPA professionals 
reviewed project activities and visited the project areas (except Obe because of security concerns). 
They used the rapid environmental assessment checklist to evaluate the subproject. They found no 
significant impacts. The project strategy of rehabilitating and expanding existing systems to improve 
the  reliability  of  diversions  and  efficiency  of  water  use,  combined  with  groundwater  resource 
evaluation and use, and institutional development is expected to result in positive environmental 
impacts. 
 
13.  Potential  Environmental  Concerns  from  Project  Location.  Possible  concerns  from 
project location include water-use conflicts and quality deterioration in areas of water scarcity, 
particularly in the dry season. However, an analysis of groundwater recharge and of its return to the 
river that will result from the increase in water diverted indicates that the gross volume of water 
available downriver of Jui Nau through groundwater seepage into the river will increase by about 
44%, thus reducing water scarcity and conflicts. Groundwater activities will be monitored by the 
environmental monitoring unit. Unexploded ordnance and land mines are concerns throughout 
Afghanistan, yet in the case of the Jui Nau, these do not appear to pose threats.4 No negative 
impacts are related to the location.  
 
14.  Potential Environmental Concerns from Project Design. Design considerations relate to 
ensuring that structures are designed for ease of farmer operation. This has been ensured with 
appropriate  design  standards.  Ease  of  use  will  be  monitored  by  the  Project’s  environmental 
monitoring unit and MEW. Thus no negative impacts are due to project design.  
 
15.  Potential  Environmental  Concerns  from  Project  Construction.  Temporary  negative 
impacts are related to noise, dust, silt, and temporary interference with irrigation. This latter concern 
will be mitigated by scheduling construction in the off-season. When closing a canal is necessary, 
farmers  have  agreed  to  dig  temporary  canals.  All  construction  contracts  will  require  qualified 
personnel  and  proper  equipment,  and  organization  to  ensure  the  implementation  of  good 
engineering practices and the use environment-friendly products. Thus no long term negative 
impacts are due to project construction. 
 
16.  Potential Environmental Concerns from Project Operations. Water and soil quality may 
be affected as a result of using more agrichemicals in selected subprojects. The potential negative 
effects will be ameliorated by extension and awareness services provided by the Project and the 
Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Husbandry, and Food. Given that each subproject is small and 
confined to existing agricultural lands, cumulative impacts will be small. The Project is not anticpated 
to result in any major downstream impacts. 
 
                                                 
4  In areas where unexploded ordnance or mines are perceived to cause a threat, the Government will be responsible 
for securing the area before any project activities can take place.

Appendix 12  59
E.  Institutional Requirements and Environmental Management Plan  
17.  Methodology.  All  relevant  laws,  regulations,  and  pending  legislation  will  need  to  be 
reviewed. During this review, consultations and interviews with relevant Government agencies, 
international organizations, NGOs, and individuals will be held to obtain a range of ideas and to 
obtain additional source material. After the legislative, regulatory, and source material review is 
complete, a second set of meetings should be held to discuss the knowledge gained. 
 
18.  Based on the IEEs, stakeholder consultation, and the ADB and NEPA guidelines and 
requirements, a project-specific set of environmental assessment and review procedures were 
prepared. An environmental management plan (EMP) was prepared to ensure that the Project has 
no future significant negative environmental problems. The plan is an intrinsic part of all project 
components. Initially, the EMP will focus on monitoring water quantity, soil and water quality, 
construction activities, and biodiversity as a function of land cover. As implementation proceeds the 
EMP will be refined, based on public consultations, ongoing data collection, and the monitoring of 
designs and construction activities. Satellite imagery will be used to monitor land use and hillside 
erosion. The EMP will also provide training. In the case of the Jui Nau subproject about $10,470 is 
provided for environmental management to cover the costs of IEE and planning activities 31.2%, 
mitigation management and training 14.9%, consultants 27.5%, and equipment 26.4%. (a draft EMP 
is presented with the IEE in Supplementary Appendix D, and environmental assessment and review 
procedures are included in Supplementary Appendix E). 
 
19.  Initially soil and water samples will be taken at larger than 2,000 ha subproject intakes and 
at no less than one canal tail within the system. The sampling network will be refined as knowledge 
is gained about the spatial variation of environmental variables. Environmental activities will be 
described in project reports and specific reports will be prepared for sampling results and training 
activities. IEs and a summary IEE will be reported. The Project will have an ongoing series of new 
subprojects, MEW officials supported by project staff will prepare an IEE for each. To assist these 
local officials and staff to prepare the IEEs and to undertake the EMP, the Project will field an 
environment specialist for 12 person-months over the first 4 years of the Project. The specialist will 
be  responsible  for  building  local  capacity,  working  with  Herat  officials  and  staff  to  design 
environmental studies and the M&E program, use and refining subproject environmental screening 
criteria; and conducting IEEs for proposed subprojects. 
 
20.  Environmental monitoring is integrated into the project monitoring and evaluation program 
and will be put into effect by the project environmental unit staff with consultant support. The Project 
has over $400,000 to support environmental activities and ensure monitoring and any mitigation is 
adequate. Monitoring is necessary to ensure that (i) the quality of water resources is not degraded, 
and (ii) the quantity of water available to tail end users within systems and to down river users 
between systems is not decreased. Resource requirements and costs include the provision for 
NEPA and for local staff to prepare IEE’s in project years 4 through 7. 
 
F.  Public Consultation and Disclosure 
21.  Stakeholder consultations were conducted individually and jointly by the TA team members 
including  the  on-farm  irrigation  engineer,  irrigation  engineer,  gender  specialist,  watershed 
management specialist, and social specialist and were held at subproject, district, and national 
levels. After the completion of the draft final report and its presentation in Kabul, a final series of on-
site subproject public consultations were conducted by the project environmental specialist and the 
two NEPA officials. Stakeholders were notified 1 week in advance with written invitations sent to 
relevant  NGOs.  These  consultations  were  held  at  the  district  headquarters  of Injil  District  for

60  Appendix 12 
stakeholders from the Jui Nau on 26 June 2005. The proceedings of the consultation in Injil for the 
Jui Nau were videotaped and televised on Herat television’s evening news. This informed a larger 
audience about proposed project activities. 
 
22.  The  issues  raised  were  the  (i)  project  objectives;  (ii)  types  of  rehabilitation  for  each 
subproject and the associated extension activities; (iii) potential environmental impacts, especially 
those related to downstream water use and historic structures; (iv) proposed strengthening of the 
mirab system; and (v) proposed mitigation measures. The attending stakeholders were asked for 
their views and opinions. They raised no additional environmental considerations and indicated that 
they did not consider the environmental issues discussed to be problems. They were unanimous in 
favoring the interventions. Information on the number and categories of stakeholders present are 
presented  in  the  IEE  (Supplementary  Appendix  D).  Project  staff  will  undertake  future  public 
consultations and disclosures. These will describe and discuss project components and activities, 
including the potential to improve soil and water conditions in the project areas. The first formal 
consultations are to take place before the design phase. 
 
G.  Conclusions 
23.  The IEEs find that the Project provides for environment-friendly irrigation interventions 
and contributes to improving living conditions. The findings of this IEE are that a follow-up 
environmental  impact  assessment  or  further  detailed  environmental  impact  study  is  not 
required. The identified potential adverse effects will be addressed through proper site location, 
planning,  design,  implementation,  and  operation  and  maintenance,  while  incorporating 
mitigation measures. The screening of future subprojects will be done in accordance with NEPA 
regulations  and  the  environmental  assessment  and  review  procedures.  Monitoring  will  be 
carried out throughout the subproject life to ensure that the guidelines are adhered to and that 
adequate capacity development is provided for all stakeholders. Although an environmental 
impact assessment is not necessary, the fielding of an environmental specialist is required to 
provide support to the project environmental monitoring unit, assist with the environmental 
screening of future subprojects and the preparation of the required IEEs, and train communities 
in the early detection of environmental degradation.
